36.text:
Who is Heathcliff? Well, it's the question
the novel keeps asking and I'm not sure really

40.text:
that it ever answers it – because he has
so many contradictory qualities. You know,

44.text:
at the beginning, he's the most poor, the
most dejected - the whole family reject him

50.text:
- but then when he comes back, he's like the
landlord from hell. He becomes this extraordinary,

56.text:
powerful, charismatic character, who usurps
the place of the family that first took him

62.text:
in. And you know, the novel gives you various
clues, yet he's picked up in Liverpool - well,

67.text:
Liverpool's a great port, so he could be from
Ireland - so the Brontë family come from

73.text:
Ireland. Patrick comes from Ireland, so he
may have fled from the terrible famine that

78.text:
was there in the 1840s. But then again, Liverpool's
a big colonial port, so he's often called

85.text:
‘black’ or - Nellie says, “you might
be an Indian Prince", so there may be some

91.text:
racial difference too, that's there in Heathcliff.
But the novel never really resolves that and

96.text:
never really tells you more than the barest
minimum - we don't know his name, we don't

101.text:
know who his parents are, he's only got a
single name - that's Heathcliff, he doesn't

106.text:
have a surname - don't know if it's a surname
or a Christian name and all we know is what

111.text:
he does and they're often very violent things,
very cruel things - it's a revenge story is

118.text:
Wuthering Heights and people often remember
the first half of the book, but the second

122.text:
half, where Heathcliff is so cruelly vengeful
to the family that initially took him in and

128.text:
so determined to be powerful, show you another
very different side of him.

142.text:
So, there are lots of literary antecedents
for Heathcliff. You know, in some ways he's

145.text:
a Byronic figure - he draws on that tradition
of the mad, bad, dangerous Lord Byron. He's

151.text:
also a bit like a Gothic character too, in
that he's a violent sexual man, who often

158.text:
imprisons younger women and is not somebody
you'd want safely to be married to. He's also

164.text:
got a supernatural air to him, of course.
They call him a ghoul and an afreet - they

169.text:
worry if he's Satanic or he's somehow in touch
with supernatural kinds of powers.

174.text:
So, Charlotte Brontë, when she writes the
preface to Emily's novel, she says here, ‘Heathcliff

180.text:
never swerves once from his arrow-straight
course to perdition’, like he's going to

185.text:
hell from the beginning, she said. Now I think
it's a more complex and subtle novel than

190.text:
that, but it shows what a disturbing figure
Heathcliff is to Charlotte and to many later readers.
